an6.55:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an6.55:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Soṇa was staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Grove.
an6.55:1.4: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
an6.55:1.5: “I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.
an6.55:1.6: Yet my mind is not freed from defilements by not grasping. But my family has wealth. I could enjoy that wealth and make merit.
an6.55:1.7: Why don’t I resign the training and return to a lesser life, so I can enjoy my wealth and make merit?”
an6.55:2.1: Then the Buddha knew what Venerable Soṇa was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the Vulture’s Peak and reappeared in the Cool Grove in front of Soṇa,
an6.55:2.2: and sat on the seat spread out.
an6.55:2.3: Soṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
an6.55:3.1: “Soṇa, as you were in private retreat didn’t this thought come to your mind:
an6.55:3.2: ‘I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.
an6.55:3.3: Yet my mind is not freed from defilements by not grasping. But my family has wealth. I could enjoy that wealth and make merit.
an6.55:3.4: Why don’t I resign the training and return to a lesser life, so I can enjoy my wealth and make merit?’”
an6.55:4.2: When you were still a layman, weren’t you a good player of the arched harp?”
an6.55:4.4: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too tight, was it resonant and playable?”
an6.55:5.1: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too slack, was it resonant and playable?”
an6.55:6.1: “But when your harp’s strings were tuned neither too tight nor too slack, but fixed at an even tension, was it resonant and playable?”
an6.55:7.1: “In the same way, Soṇa, when energy is too forceful it leads to restlessness. When energy is too slack it leads to laziness.
an6.55:7.2: So, Soṇa, you should focus on energy and serenity, find a balance of the faculties, and learn the character of this situation.”
an6.55:7.4: After advising Soṇa like this, the Buddha, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Cool Grove and reappeared on the Vulture’s Peak.
an6.55:8.1: After some time Soṇa focused on energy and serenity, found a balance of the faculties, and learned the pattern of this situation.
an6.55:8.2: Then Soṇa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
an6.55:8.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
an6.55:8.4: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected.
an6.55:9.1: Then, when Soṇa had attained perfection, he thought,
an6.55:9.2: “Why don’t I go to the Buddha and declare my enlightenment in his presence?”
an6.55:9.3: Then Soṇa went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an6.55:10.1: “Sir, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—is dedicated to six things.
an6.55:10.2: They are dedicated to renunciation, seclusion, kindness, the ending of craving, the ending of grasping, and mental clarity.
an6.55:11.1: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:
an6.55:11.2: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to renunciation solely out of mere faith.’
an6.55:11.3: But it should not be seen like this.
an6.55:11.4: A mendicant with defilements ended does not see in themselves anything more to do, or anything that needs improvement. They’re dedicated to renunciation because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
an6.55:12.1: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:
an6.55:12.2: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to seclusion because they enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity.’
an6.55:12.3: But it should not be seen like this. …
an6.55:13.1: It may be, sir, that one of the venerables here thinks:
an6.55:13.2: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to kindness because they believe that adhering to precepts and observances is essential.’
an6.55:13.3: But it should not be seen like this. …
an6.55:14.1: They’re dedicated to the ending of craving because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
an6.55:15.1: They’re dedicated to the ending of grasping because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
an6.55:16.1: They’re dedicated to clarity of mind because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
an6.55:17.1: When a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t overcome their mind.
an6.55:17.2: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
an6.55:17.7: and ideas come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome the mind.
an6.55:17.8: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
an6.55:17.9: Suppose there was a mountain that was one solid mass of rock, without cracks or holes.
an6.55:17.10: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south,
an6.55:17.12: they couldn’t make it shake or rock or tremble.
an6.55:17.13: In the same way, when a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t overcome their mind. …
an6.55:17.20: Their mind is quite untainted. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
an6.55:19.1: when you’re dedicated to the ending of craving
an6.55:19.3: and you’ve seen the arising of the senses,
an6.55:22.1: and ideas, whether liked or disliked,
an6.55:22.3: Their mind is steady and free
